title: 111_hr3737
content: The "Small Business Microlending Expansion Act of 2009" allows for a Microloan Credit Building Initiative, requiring intermediaries to report borrower information to credit agencies. Additionally, the Act introduces Flexible Credit Terms. SEC. 3. FLEXIBLE CREDIT TERMS. Amends the Small Business Act to remove "short-term" from certain paragraphs. SEC. 4. INCREASED PROGRAM PARTICIPATION. Section 7(m)(2) of the Small Business Act is amended to require individuals involved in making microloans to have at least 1 year of experience or 1 full-time employee with 3 years of experience in working with startup, newly established, or growing small businesses. The Small Business Act now requires individuals involved in making microloans to have at least 1 year of experience or 1 full-time employee with 3 years of experience in working with small businesses. This employee must also provide intensive marketing, management, and technical assistance to borrowers. The Small Business Act now mandates individuals making microloans to have 1 year of experience or 1 full-time employee with 3 years of experience in assisting small businesses with marketing, management, and technical support. SEC. 5 increases the limit on intermediary borrowing to $1,000,000 and $7,000,000, with the option to treat it as $10,000,000 if deemed appropriate. SEC. 6 expands borrower education assistance to 35 percent. SEC. 7 introduces the Young Entrepreneurs Program. The Small Business Act is amended to include a Young Entrepreneurs Program for providing technical assistance to young entrepreneurs in establishing or operating small businesses and acquiring financing. The Young Entrepreneurs Program provides technical assistance for young entrepreneurs to establish small businesses and secure financing in a specific geographic area. A young entrepreneur is defined as an individual under 25 years old who has lived in the area for at least 2 years. The Young Entrepreneurs Program offers technical assistance to individuals under 25 years old who have resided in the program's geographic area for at least 2 years. If they establish a small business, they must make efforts to operate it in the same area. The Young Entrepreneurs Program provides technical assistance to individuals under 25 who have lived in the program's area for 2 years. If they start a small business, they must operate it in the same geographic area. Repayment on loans for these businesses can be deferred for up to 6 months. SEC. 8. INTEREST RATES AND LOAN SIZE amended to increase loan size from $7,500 to $10,000 in various paragraphs. SEC. 9. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a reporting requirement for the microloan program. The Administrator must submit a report to the House and Senate Committees on Small Business, detailing the names and locations of intermediaries receiving funds, along with loan and grant amounts provided in each fiscal year. The report required under Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act must include details on intermediaries receiving funds for microloans, including loan and grant amounts, contributions from non-Federal sources, and the number and amounts of microloans made to specific groups such as women, low-income, and veteran entrepreneurs. The report under Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act must detail intermediaries receiving funds for microloans, including loan and grant amounts, contributions from non-Federal sources, and the number and amounts of microloans made to specific groups like women, low-income, veteran, disabled, and minority entrepreneurs. It should also describe the marketing, management, and technical assistance provided to these borrowers. The report must detail the marketing, management, and technical assistance provided by intermediaries to borrowers, including women, low-income, veteran, disabled, and minority entrepreneurs, as well as the number of jobs created and retained as a result of microloans. The report must include details on the number of jobs created and retained, repayment history, and success of businesses after receiving microloans from intermediaries, including minority entrepreneurs. SEC. 10. Surplus interest rate subsidy for businesses. The Administrator can provide grants to intermediaries to reduce interest rates for borrowers under this subsection. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2010 and 2011 under the Small Business Act, including $80,000,000 in technical assistance grants, $110,000,000 in direct loans, and $10,000,000 in interest assistance grants. Authorization of necessary appropriations for these programs. SEC. 12. REGULATIONS. The Administrator must issue regulations within 180 days of the enactment of this Act to carry out its provisions. Passed the House of Representatives on November 7, 2009.
